description: From Middle English etik, ethik, from Old French etique, from Medieval Latin *hecticus, from Ancient Greek ἑκτικός (hektikós, “habitual, hectic, consumptive”), from ἕξις (héxis, “a state or habit of body or of mind, condition”), from ἔχειν (ékhein, “to have, hold, intransitive be in a certain state”).

adjectives.description: hectic (comparative more hectic, superlative most hectic)

entries.meaning: (figurative) Very busy with activity and confusion.
examples: The city center is so hectic at 8 in the morning that I go to work an hour beforehand to avoid the crowds

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Denoting a type of fever accompanying consumption and similar wasting diseases, characterised by flushed cheeks and dry skin.
(obsolete) Pertaining to or symptomatic of such a fever.
(obsolete) A flush like one produced by such a fever.
